Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I was hunched over my laptop, fingers flying across the keyboard as I tried to refactor the last bit of code for the new feature. The deadline was looming, and my team had just flagged some performance issues in the code review. My mind raced with possible solutions, each one more complex than the last. I barely registered the sound of footsteps until I glanced up and saw my step-brother, hoodie half-zipped, heading for the front door. He was glued to his phone, not paying attention as he pushed the door open. Through the window, I saw him step onto the curb, eyes still on his screen, about to cross the street. My heart pounded. I knew I should call out, make sure he looked both ways—Mom always said we had to look out for each other. But my screen blinked with another review comment, and I felt the weight of my team’s expectations pressing down. I was torn, caught between the urge to protect my brother and the demand to deliver perfect code. My hands hovered, uncertain, between the keyboard and the window.
